The gunplay is acceptable, provided you have the resources to buy gun parts – my primary gripe with the game being its pay-to-win format. If I could look past that, the game has some redeeming qualities, such as the entertaining hardsuit mechanics and innovative HRV feature. However, the pay-to-win microtransaction model remains a turnoff for me. If you're comfortable with this type of monetization, feel free to give it a try. Otherwise, like me, you might want to pass on this one since it doesn't align with our preference for non-pay-to-win games.

Although not flawless, this game has been immensely enjoyable. The save system and risk of unexpected death have led to occasional frustration, such as when I lost my primary character around hour 10 of my first playthrough. A save-and-reload feature would have been helpful then. To mitigate this issue, I've adopted a third-party mod/save tool. Additionally, the aiming reticle could be larger, and the zoom function slightly more powerful. Despite these minor drawbacks, the game has been incredibly engaging; I'm not typically a fan of zombie games, but the mix of strategic elements, missions, first-person shooting, and beat-em-up mechanics has captivated me. My playtime has been frequent, often leaving me eager for 'just one more mission' or 'one more supply run' before calling it quits.

This is an absolutely fantastic strategy game! Having played every other wargame in the series (European Escalation and Alb), I can confidently say that this installment fits perfectly into the franchise. The sheer number of units available is impressive - I won't give away the exact count, but let's just say there are plenty! The graphics are breathtaking, the sound design is superb, and the gameplay is truly epic. Even the in-game chat box at the main menu provides some entertainment value. Be warned though, this game isn't a walk in the park, especially for those new to the strategy genre. It may take some time to master, and you'll likely lose a few units along the way. But don't worry, with careful planning, a strong emphasis on anti-air and anti-tank measures, and perseverance, victory will be within your grasp.

I had reservations about Portal 2 before playing it, unsure if I wanted to invest in the game. My skepticism stemmed from my initial confusion about the concept of portal guns and portals, despite my fondness for science fiction. However, my doubts were quickly dispelled once I started playing. The humor and voice acting in the game are truly exceptional, striking the perfect balance between wit and silliness. Each character has a distinct personality, showcased through their unique brand of humor. Additionally, the level design is inventive and engaging. While I haven't played the original Portal, I'm eager to try it out someday when I have the chance. In fact, I might not have ever tried Portal 2 if I hadn't been convinced by its excellence.

"Let's start with the pros (+) and cons (-) before sharing my thoughts on this game. The game offers some of the best characters, a good storyline, loads of content, customizable character options (including gender preference), and the ability to pursue romantic relationships with most companions. However, it does have some drawbacks such as poor graphics, awkward love scenes, invisible walls, and a few dull missions. One thing to note is that your protagonist cannot speak, but this isn't necessarily a negative aspect for me. Overall, I love this game! It's probably one of the best RPGs or games in general that I've ever played, so if you're an RPG fan, you likely already own it."

For those in their thirties, playing this game might evoke nostalgic memories of watching the annoying Timmy Mallett on TV, all for the sake of catching the briefTransformers cartoon. Thankfully, the voice cast reprises their iconic roles, including Optimus Prime, Megatron, Bumblebee, and numerous others, which adds to the game's charm. The signature transformation sound effects are also unmistakably Generation One. Visually, the cel-shaded graphics are flawless, capturing the retro feel without any compromise. While the game may seem like a mere throwback at first glance, its combat mechanics deserve high praise. Transformation plays a crucial role in combat, often requiring you to change forms mid-battle, which flows smoothly into combination attacks. Unlike High Moon's War for/Fall of Cybertron titles, this game emphasizes melee combat, although certain foes, such as Seekers, demand a strategic shift to ranged weaponry.

I downloaded the game and played it for a brief period, but it didn't impress me. In fact, I spent more time attempting to log in than I did playing the game. There's a frustrating bug that prevents successful login; every time I tried to accept the updated terms of service, the prompt would simply reappear. The only solution is to restart the client. While this issue isn't catastrophic, I'm annoyed that I'm required to link my Steam and GFace accounts. The supposed reason for this is to receive DLC, but I question its necessity. Moreover, once linked, the connection cannot be undone, which means a company I have no interest in now has access to my Steam information. As for the game itself, it's unremarkable and blatantly inspired by Call of Duty. Somehow, the developers managed to make the gunplay inferior to the original, which is a remarkable achievement.

"The game offers 4K resolution at 60 frames per second, thanks to the GTX 970, and features dual audio options. Plus, it includes Neptune Gear! What's not to love? The YouTube video linked below showcases an excellent port and serves as a great entry point for those new to the series. Keep in mind that there is some skippable dialogue, but feel free to use either a gamepad or a keyboard and mouse configuration, both of which are fully rebindable. At its price point, I wouldn't have hesitated to make a purchase, especially considering over half of the DLC is included for free, providing ample content to enjoy. This game comes highly recommended for fans of JRPGs, anime, and visual novels, though be prepared for occasional lengthy breaks between actions. Check out the link to a commentary-free playlist below."

I didn't encounter any performance issues at launch, and after all the patches, the game runs smoothly. In my opinion, this is a truly entertaining and engaging game, despite some minor frustrations with the format (specifically, the free-roam city area respawning new enemies as you progress through the story). The "dual play" segments, where I could play as Batman accompanied by another character, were especially enjoyable. Additionally, having the option to switch between using a controller and mouse and keyboard for different parts of the game, such as the tank combat sequences, was much appreciated. Lastly, once I got the hang of using the brakes to skid around corners while driving the Batmobile, cruising around the free-roam city became genuinely enjoyable, and later on, it became second nature.

Damn fine aaa fps shooter - that's the bottom line. The game boasts impressive visuals, engaging gameplay, a compelling narrative, memorable characters, flawless voice acting, and an epic soundtrack. However, it's not suitable for the faint of heart, as some cutscenes can be quite graphic and intense. While the game's overall quality makes its few flaws more noticeable, I did encounter a couple of issues: lack of SLI support, which forced me to upgrade my GPU; and occasionally, small obstacles that proved surprisingly difficult to climb. Nonetheless, ensure you have a relatively powerful single GPU card before diving into this thrilling experience.

"I'm not a native English speaker; I'm Dutch. Please excuse any typing or grammatical errors in my review of this excellent game. I'll break it down into several categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, replayability, and graphics. The game features a comic-inspired art style, and the visuals are sleek and polished. There are no unnecessary details, and the color schemes are great. The graphics can be set to high without putting too much strain on your system. I run the game on an Intel Core i5 processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710M GPU and 8GB of RAM under Windows 8.1, and it performs smoothly. The game supports both keyboard and mouse input as well as Xbox controllers."

I have spent countless hours playing this game, which speaks to my enjoyment of it. It's everything I wanted a search game from COD to be. However, don't assume that it's similar to COD, Battlefield, or any other first-person shooter game. It's a unique experience in its own right, and players should approach it as such. I've heard too many new players complaining about getting killed quickly, as if they expect to be invincible. Newsflash: dying is part of the game, just like in real life. After sinking considerable time and money into it, I can confidently say that it's one of the best multiplayer games out there, perfect for when you need a break from CS:GO.

"Two hours into the game, I'm already hooked and thoroughly entertained. The gameplay is engaging, the art design is stunning, the music is impressive, and the storyline is intriguing. But what truly sets this game apart is its sense of humor. As someone who has played their fair share of RPGs, I can confidently say that the jokes, parodies, and references are spot-on and hilarious. Even if you're new to the genre, the game's humor is sure to bring a smile to your face. And let's just say that fans of Final Fantasy 7 or X are in for a real treat. I found myself having to take breaks every now and then to recover from the constant barrage of laughter and smiles. It's been a true delight so far."

I apologize sincerely, as I genuinely attempt to advocate for free-to-play games and independent developers. Unfortunately, this particular title failed to impress me despite its promising description. As an enthusiast of puzzle and exploration games, I was excited about the prospect of immersing myself in this experience. However, I found the gameplay to be utterly unintuitive, which made progression difficult even after consulting guides. Moreover, the absence of a pause button – or at least, one that I couldn't locate – proved problematic since many sequences feature time constraints. This omission feels particularly glaring given the game's emphasis on timing. Additionally, I felt that the game relies excessively on cutscenes, leaving me idle for extended periods, eagerly awaiting the opportunity to engage with the gameplay.

Wow, where do I even begin? This game was stunningly beautiful, both in terms of its captivating narrative and breathtaking visuals. From the get-go, I found myself completely immersed in the story, feeling as though I was the protagonist uncovering the mysteries of the plot. The gameplay was engaging and challenging, and I discovered a lot about myself through the experience - including my previously unknown fear of heights, which was triggered by the nerve-wracking ice caverns! Despite the anxiety it caused me, I persevered for Uncle Fred's sake, and I'm thrilled that I did. If there's ever a DLC or sequel, I'll be the first in line to purchase it and recommend it to all my friends. Kudos to every single person involved in creating this masterpiece; you've crafted a truly exceptional gaming experience.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based strategy game where you aim to build a civilization towards a specific objective or "victory." Unlike its predecessors, which followed Earth's historical timeline through eras like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age, this installment takes place in the future, tasking players with colonizing a new planet. One aspect I appreciate about this game is how 2K Games introduced fresh mechanics, such as the affinity system and orbital layer, providing a unique twist to the series. However, I found the addition of these features also made the game overwhelming at times. To further enhance the player's experience, incorporating more diverse environmental artwork during diplomatic interactions with other leaders would be a welcome improvement.

Great game! Tons of replayability and very fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. After logging over 60 hours, I can confidently say that this is one of the better, more realistic zombie games out there. The gameplay is designed like a true survival horror experience, where you must carefully manage your ammo, heal your own wounds when you bleed out, and take pills to cure infections. The zombies are also impressively lifelike, especially considering it's a free-to-play game. While playing with friends is always recommended, the community is super friendly, and you can easily make new friends or engage in chat or voice comms. Overall, this game offers an immersive and thrilling experience that any zombie game enthusiast would enjoy.

February 7th, 2014 - It's unfortunate that I cannot wholeheartedly recommend or enjoy this game, despite its potential for addiction. The lack of Australian servers significantly hinders my experience, as a single red bar results in a substantial disadvantage and intolerable lag. Notably, the offline training mode still experiences stuttering and lag, which raises concerns about the game's optimization. Additionally, the abundance of graphical artifacts, including distortions in menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game elements, detracts from the overall quality. Although I initially suspected that my overclocked GPU might be the cause, reverting it to stock settings did not resolve the issue.

I completed this game very late last night, and while the story may not be particularly deep or captivating, the exceptional storytelling and immersive atmosphere make it stand out. The numerous collectibles do an excellent job of fleshing out the world of Batman, although I did find it somewhat disappointing that there were only a few boss battles throughout the game. Nevertheless, there are plenty of opportunities for future games to address this. The combat system offers just the right amount of challenge, leaning slightly towards the easier side. However, leveling up Batman didn't feel as rewarding as I had hoped. Instead, it was the various gadgets and abilities that I upgraded and acquired throughout the campaign that added fresh gameplay mechanics and made exploring previously inaccessible areas a thrilling experience.

'To the Moon' is far more than just a game; it's a deeply immersive and emotionally resonant experience that left me awestruck. Among the most memorable experiences of my life, it surpasses even The Walking Dead in its emotional impact. I've rarely felt such a mix of profound sorrow and satisfaction from a work of fiction. This masterpiece represents the zenith of storytelling, complemented by a beautifully crafted soundtrack that perfectly captures the mood. Although the controls can be slightly tricky, and the gameplay may not be the main draw, the narrative is so exceptional that I found myself completely absorbed. Moreover, the game's sense of humor is delightful and doesn't detract from the gravity of the story. In fact, Doctor Who fans will appreciate the numerous nods to the beloved franchise scattered throughout.

Bastion is an incredibly engaging game with a captivating storyline. After a catastrophic event, the game takes place in a world where you must rebuild and restore order. The game offers numerous choices that impact your playstyle, such as deciding which structures to construct, which weapons to wield, and which power-ups and bonuses to utilize. The vibrant art style and immersive soundtrack complement the post-apocalyptic setting, making the game feel anything but dull. One of the standout features is the dynamic narration, which responds to your actions as a player, adding a unique touch to the gameplay experience. For example, if you swap out one weapon for another, the narrator will acknowledge your decision, further immerging you in the game's world.

I purchased this game during its early development phase when the sole currency was spacebux and there was no such thing as a "tech tree." This was a great time to play the game, as all weapons were balanced, meaning there was no issue with imbalance, and anyone could kill anyone at any given moment. Additionally, the game offered unlimited gun slots and five loadouts, which was generous considering the vast array of weapons available. However, I felt that with so many weapons, the game should have provided more than six weapon slots and three loadouts without requiring payment for additional upgrades. In fact, at one point, I had amassed around three pages' worth of guns and was brainstorming new ideas for more, as that aspect of the game was particularly enjoyable for me.

This game turned out to be a hidden gem, defying my initial expectations. While some product reviews can be misleading, in this case, they accurately reflected the game's entertainment value. It seamlessly blends elements of a classic 2D platformer and MOBA, making it a unique and stylish experience. I found myself enjoying characters that I wouldn't typically prefer in other MOBA games. Curious about its mechanics, I decided to try out a melee tank character, and much to my surprise, I enjoyed playing it. In fact, I became so engrossed that I continued to play and unlock more characters. The game's quirky art style and user-friendly interface only added to its charm, prompting me to adopt one of the characters as my avatar and create a card set featuring its distinctive visuals.

I'm thoroughly enjoying this game, having recently started playing. I can easily get lost in it for hours at a time, donning my headphones and immersing myself in the engaging gameplay. It's been a while since a game has had such a captivating effect on me. The music creates an atmosphere that complements the game perfectly, while the sound effects are spot on. The controls are also well-designed, making combat encounters a sheer delight. In fact, I eagerly anticipate each skirmish, as the developers have done an excellent job optimizing the combat mechanics. My initial doubts about the naval combat system were quickly dispelled once I experienced the thrill of decimating numerous fleets simultaneously. The key to success? Knowing when to retreat and regroup before launching a counterattack. Kudos to the development team for delivering an exceptional gaming experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has brought significant changes, especially for the series' protagonist, Dante. Although some fans of the original series may feel nostalgic about the update, the revamped game by Ninja Theory has proven it was worth the transformation. Serving as an excellent entry point for new players, DMC showcases the evolution of an initially arrogant and cynical Dante, tracing his journey towards selflessness. The game masterfully crafts a distinct narrative arc for the new Dante, making him an intriguing character to follow. The story unfolds as Dante is drawn into a corrupt world he had previously chosen to disregard.

I am thoroughly impressed by this game's captivating story, which is full of charm and attention to detail. It's a delightful mix of humor, endearing characters, and unexpected secrets. What sets it apart from other RPGs is its unique approach to conflict resolution - you don't have to kill anyone, which is a refreshing change of pace. The character designs are well thought out, each with their own distinct personalities and backstories. The game's inspirations from Earthbound are evident, making it stand out even more. Additionally, the soundtrack is simply superb, adding another layer of depth to the overall experience.

I recommend this only because it's free, and it might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. Personally, the "game" didn't impress me; its impact relied heavily on shock value, which failed to resonate with me. Perhaps I've become desensitized or the experience was too simplistic to elicit an emotional response. The second part of the game attempts to depict a person's mental deterioration through visual storytelling, addressing themes such as obsession, hallucinations, depression, and more. While the concept is intriguing, the execution fell short for me, as it took mere minutes to complete—including time spent thoroughly reading and absorbing all available details.

Portal is an incredible game that truly showcases the power of innovative design. The concept is straightforward: you're given a set of tools, and then left to figure out how to use them to solve increasingly complex puzzles. What makes Portal so remarkable is its ability to challenge your mind without ever feeling tedious or overwhelming. Even though it doesn't have a dense narrative, it has become a cult classic and spawned one of the most beloved games of 2011. I still enjoy playing it years later, both for the nostalgia factor and to appreciate the foundation of a gaming legend. The gameplay itself is surprisingly simple. You manipulate portals and buttons to progress through each level. There are two types of buttons - ones you can press yourself, and others that require a cube to activate. With these basic elements, Portal manages to create a rich and engaging experience that continues to captivate players.

If you can ignore the few bugs I encountered (one minor and another slightly more frustrating), which have since been addressed with a patch that significantly boosted my frame rate from 60-90 to 80-120, and you're seeking a space exploration game, then I wholeheartedly recommend this title. Most reviews focus on system specifications, so here are mine: an Intel Core i5 6600K (approximately €200), Radeon RX480 graphics card (also around €200), Z170 Pro Gaming motherboard (about €150), and 16GB DDR4 RAM (costing roughly €70). While the total cost of approximately €650 falls within the mid-range budget category, it's worth mentioning that this hardware is relatively new. The game consistently delivers high settings with VSYNC enabled at 60+ frames per second, making it difficult to comprehend how some commenters claim to be running superior setups but struggle with low frame rates.

Do you remember Age of Mythology? It's been that long since we've had an RTS game of such quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes remarkably close to being my new favorite RTS game. Its combination with a grand strategy mode similar to Risk hits the sweet spot for me. I must admit, I have a soft spot for games that allow me to transform into a dragon and aid my troops by supporting, attacking, and commanding unit production, direction, and spawning simultaneously. While I enjoy the complexity of modern RTS games like Civilization V, they often feel cluttered, trying to pack too many mechanics, charts, and resources into a single game mode.

Undertale is a masterclass in synergy, where every element blends seamlessly to create a work greater than the sum of its parts. While the graphics are impressive for a retro-style game, the soundtrack stands out as particularly memorable, elevating key moments to new heights. The writing is equally exceptional, deftly navigating a range of emotions – from humor to drama, heartbreak to hope – often within the same scene, all while subverting RPG conventions. With so much to offer, including engaging characters, captivating storytelling, and innovative gameplay mechanics, it's essential playing material for anyone remotely interested in role-playing games or video games in general. In fact, even those with limited time should prioritize experiencing Undertale before their final breath.

If you enjoyed The Witcher 1 and 2, then The Witcher 3 is a must-play. I would typically give this game a perfect score of 10/10, but unfortunately, it has been marred by bugs and random crashes since the 1.03 update. Prior to that, I didn't experience any issues during my playthrough from version 1.00 to 1.03, and the game ran smoothly. However, after the 1.03 patch, the drawing distance has occasionally been poor, only rendering objects or characters when I'm very close. Despite these technical issues, the game remains exceptional, with a tremendous amount of effort put into creating engaging quests, many of which are emotionally resonant and deeply personal. The sheer volume of side quests and the impact of player choices make it a truly immersive experience. I've sunk over 50 hours into the game and am still eager to continue.

I've had this game for only a few months, and yet, two DLCs have already been released, accompanied by patches that have enhanced an already great game into an exceptional experience. The developers are actively engaged with the community, as evident in the various discussion forums and dev diaries. While there is a challenging learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I'm still in the process of mastering, the depth of strategy offers numerous approaches to achieving goals and capitalizing on situational opportunities. In my opinion, the game is highly replayable, as each session pulls me in, regardless of how the playthrough unfolds.

Warframe offers an initially entertaining experience, providing several enjoyable hours of gameplay. However, as you progress, you may find that the game's combat, enemy designs, and overall gameplay become increasingly repetitive. Despite this drawback, the developers actively update the game with substantial content, including revamped systems, new warframes, and various tweaks. These updates demonstrate their commitment to enhancing the player's experience. While Warframe remains a suitable option for casual gaming, its longevity may be limited due to the repetitive nature of its core mechanics. Nevertheless, since the game is free, I would still suggest giving it a try if you seek a brief gaming escape.

"I found this game to be extremely disappointing. I purchased it thinking it would be similar to 'Katamari Damacy,' a beloved PS2 game, but it fell short of my expectations. The gameplay involves growing larger by absorbing objects, but the experience is marred by clunky controls and unimaginative level design. Moreover, the game's atmosphere is eerie and unsettling, with lifeless animations that resemble taxidermied specimens rather than living creatures. The whole experience left me feeling dejected and questioning the purpose of existence."

As a politics enthusiast, I was excited to learn about this game that promised to simulate the journey to become president. My initial reaction was, "Wow, this sounds like fun!" However, my excitement quickly turned into disappointment when I realized that the game forces players to choose between Republican or Democrat, with no option for independence or third-party affiliation. Despite this limitation, I decided to continue playing to see what else the game had to offer. One aspect that surprised me was the character customization feature, which allowed me to create a personalized avatar. Although the options were somewhat restricted, it was entertaining to experiment with different looks. Notably, it was the only time during the game where I had the freedom to decide whether or not to wear a hat - a minor detail that added some humor to the experience.

The story in Fallout 3 was superior. Settlements often obstruct the narrative, making it feel like babysitting instead of enjoying the game. Unfortunately, some keys are hardcoded and cannot be remapped. The game is also plagued by numerous bugs, including instances where my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, requiring me to use console commands to retrieve it. Power armor is readily available early in the game, and power cores are abundant in traders' shops, which lessens its value compared to previous Fallout titles. While the story is unremarkable, the game's stability is a significant improvement over Fallout 3. Despite its lackluster quality, this game was heavily hyped, leading to disappointment. In comparison, it does not surpass either Fallout 3 or New Vegas.

"At the time of writing this review, I had spent 8.6 hours playing the game and had found 10 out of 25 collectibles. Unfortunately, I didn't manage to unlock any of the 15 available achievements. While there were some aspects of the game that I enjoyed, such as the visuals until the final level, the story was somewhat disappointing. However, the ending did provide a small measure of redemption after sitting through the closing credits. The visuals in the last level were rather dull, and the gameplay became significantly more challenging, leading to a frustrating experience of repetition. Additionally, the achievements were extremely difficult, with only less than 2,1% of players managing to unlock all 15."

Pros: + graphics
Cons: - bugs (particularly environmental issues that can cause players to get stuck or encounter invisible walls despite having a clear view of enemies) - too much hand-holding/babysitting - poor AI - enemies have an uncanny ability to detect the player's location once they've been spotted - frustratingly accurate enemy shooting, reminiscent of the first Ghost Warrior game - subpar checkpoint and save system - underwhelming experience with too much repetition. I wouldn't recommend purchasing this game at full price. Even at a discount of 90%, I found it to be a tedious and unengaging experience, only playing it to complete it and move on to other games in my collection. The time spent on the first Ghost Warrior game felt wasted, and I don't plan on continuing with the series.

"Do not purchase this game until further notice, as the servers are currently offline. This means that you will be unable to play the game even if you buy it. I personally had a positive experience with the game when I was able to play it, and I found myself humming the tune of Steve Miller Band's 'Take the Money and Run' whenever I thought about it. However, my enjoyment was short-lived, as I only played for 73 minutes before encountering issues with overpowered weapons and poor matchmaking. The latter led to frustrating experiences where I would shoot enemies point-blank in the face without any effect, making me feel like I was fighting against AI rather than human opponents."

Who wouldn't want to wear a fez? This puzzle-platformer game features a small character donning a fez, collecting tiny fragments to create a cube while traversing a vast, interconnected map. The game offers ample amusement, and completing it was a delightful experience. However, obtaining all the cubes and achievements can be slightly vexing, as you'll need to decipher cryptic codes. These challenges may take a few moments to solve or leave you feeling stumped, prompting you to consult a guide (I admit, I succumbed to the temptation). For those seeking a comprehensive resource, there's a helpful guide titled "A Complete Guide to Fez!!!!"

I can understand why others might enjoy this game, but unfortunately, it didn't resonate with me. As an owner of a Vive headset, I prefer immersive experiences that utilize room-scale tracking with controllers. Moreover, while the game's vast universe is certainly impressive at first, it ultimately became a hindrance to my enjoyment. The steep learning curve and significant time investment required to engage in meaningful gameplay made it difficult for me to fully appreciate the experience. If I had more patience and dedicated gaming time, perhaps I could have found it compelling. However, given my current circumstances, I find myself gravitating towards other virtual reality games that offer a more satisfying and efficient use of my time.

Hands down, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. No run-and-gun rambo tactics here - this game is all about realism. Recoil and ballistics are spot on, so don't expect to survive multiple hits from rifle-caliber weapons. A single well-placed shot to the chest, neck, or head usually means instant death, unless it merely grazes you. Rounds drop over distance, and short, controlled bursts are essential to stay on target. There's no infinite ammo supply, either; if you reload mid-magazine, you'll be left with a pouch full of half-empty clips. And forget about running nonstop - after a sprint, your aim will suffer as you struggle to catch your breath. To maintain accuracy, rest your weapon on your elbows when prone or on a stable surface like a windowsill."

I didn't buy Europa Universalis IV when it first released, but I did get it on sale, which included the expansion pack. So, I didn't experience the issues that some players claimed to have had with the game. In fact, I thoroughly enjoyed it; although, it was quite unforgiving in the early stages, the sense of accomplishment when I played it correctly made up for it. Moving on to XCOM 2, I also enjoy playing it, and it runs relatively smoothly on my GTX560 with 2GB VRAM. Initially, the game defaulted to high settings, causing slight lag, but after adjusting it to medium, the performance evened out. It's possible that I've been fortunate when it comes to encountering issues with games, but many negative reviews seem to be written by overly entitled players.

This game is incredibly enjoyable despite its flaws. Sure, there are some drawbacks such as limited equipment variety, sub-par AI teammates, and a lack of branching skill trees. However, it doesn't detract from the fact that there's still plenty of variety and strategy to be had. The game starts off strong and only gets better as you progress. Plus, even with a limited selection of equipment, there's always something new to unlock or level up, keeping the game feeling fresh. Mods are where this game truly shines, with Fight for Universe being the standout addition, closely followed by Big Fight for Beef.

World leaders are convening in Davos, Switzerland, amidst uncertainty, as over 2,000 business and political leaders from across the globe gather for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). Spanning five days, the conference will address various pressing issues, including China's growing economic influence and Iraq's future following Sunday's elections. Among the attendees are UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki, joined by some 20 other government leaders and heads of state. Notably, this year's WEF has seen anti-globalization activists cancel their previously planned weekend demonstration, while the Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will simultaneously host the alternative World Social Forum.

Fiat and General Motors (GM) are running out of time to resolve their dispute over a potential takeover, with a deadline looming on February 1st at midnight. As part of their alliance agreement in 2000, Fiat will gain the right to sell its car division to GM, but the latter no longer wishes to acquire the unprofitable unit. Recent reports of stalled negotiations caused Fiat's shares to drop by 1.2% on Tuesday, following a 4% increase on Monday fueled by hopes of a settlement. GM is reportedly offering around $2 billion (£1.06 billion) to exit the arrangement, claiming that Fiat's sale of its finance arm and reduction of GM's stake through a capital-raising effort nullified the original deal. The 2000 agreement was the result of a race between GM and DaimlerChrysler to form an alliance with Fiat.

Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has criticized the Iraq War, stating that the billions of pounds spent on the conflict in Iraq and the Middle East could have been better utilized to alleviate poverty. As the head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales, the cardinal made these remarks during an interview on BBC Radio 4 and plans to reiterate his position during his Christmas midnight mass. In his Christmas message, he denounced the war as a "terrible" waste of resources. Joining the Archbishop of Canterbury in speaking out against the war, the cardinal lamented that vast sums have been squandered on military actions rather than being directed towards lifting people "out of dire poverty, malnourishment, and disease." Instead, the cardinal advocates for making 2005 the year to "make history poverty."

British actors and filmmakers were shut out of the major Oscar categories, dashing hopes for UK success at the prestigious awards ceremony. Despite multiple nominations, Mike Leigh's critically acclaimed "Vera Drake" failed to secure Director or Screenplay honors, and Imelda Staunton was overlooked for Best Actress. Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo also fell short in their respective bids for Supporting Actor recognition. However, the UK did enjoy some success in the Short Film category, where Andrea Arnold took home the trophy for her powerful drama "Wasp." A former host of children's TV shows in the 1980s, Arnold described her victory as "completely overwhelming," particularly given the strong competition from fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a screenwriter and producer renowned for her work on the iconic 1978 horror film Halloween, passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54 after battling cancer. Hill co-wrote the movie, which stars Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter tormented by a psychopath, alongside director John Carpenter. The film achieved remarkable success, grossing over $60 million worldwide and setting a record for independent films at the time. In addition to Halloween, Hill collaborated with Carpenter on Escape from New York and The Fog. A trailblazing figure in the film industry, Hill began her career as a production assistant and worked her way up the ranks, eventually becoming an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. Her contributions paved the way for future generations of women in film, breaking down barriers in a male-dominated industry in the 1970s.

Broadband is fueling online expression, and fast web access is enticing more people to share their thoughts and ideas digitally, research indicates. According to a study conducted by UK think-tank Demos, a considerable proportion (25%) of British broadband users regularly upload content and maintain personal websites. The report highlights how having a constantly connected, high-speed internet connection is revolutionizing the way individuals utilize the web. With over five million households in the UK already equipped with broadband and the number rapidly increasing, the influence of broadband on net behavior is significant. The Demos report examined this impact and discovered that more than half of broadband users access the internet before breakfast, while one in five confessed to waking up during the night to browse online. Most notably, the report emphasizes that broadband is motivating individuals to engage more actively online, transforming them from passive consumers into creators and contributors.

Yukos, a Russian oil and gas company, is set to return to US courts on Thursday as it battles for survival. The firm faces dissolution by Russian authorities seeking to collect a $27 billion (£14 billion) tax debt. In a bid to prevent the forced sale of its primary oil production unit, Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the US and invoked international business law. Despite this move, the unit, Yuganskneftegas, was sold to state-owned Rosneft for $9.4 billion following a controversial auction marred by disruptions. Yukos' legal team argues that the auction violated US bankruptcy laws, and the company and its major shareholders are determined to pursue legal action against any entity that acquires its assets.

Voting is currently underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the best web blogs of the year. The nominations were announced on Sunday, but due to an overwhelming number of visitors, the official website was temporarily shut down. This year's nominees include weblogs in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. The popularity of blogs continues to grow, with Merriam-Webster naming "blog" the Word of the Year in 2004. According to Technorati, a blog search engine, approximately six million blogs are tracked, and over 12,000 new ones are added daily. Moreover, a blog is created every 5.8 seconds, reports Pew Internet and American Life, a US research think tank; however, less than 40% of these blogs are updated at least once every two months.

The China Three Gorges Project Corp is defying a government order to halt construction of one of its massive dams, according to the Chinese state press. Despite being told to stop work on the Xiluodu Dam, the company continues to push forward with the project, risking fines and penalties. This comes as 30 large-scale construction projects, including the Xiluodu Dam, were ordered to cease operations due to a lack of proper environmental checks. While most projects have complied with the shutdown order, the China Three Gorges Project Corp remains steadfast in its refusal to do so, even ignoring similar orders for its Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. As of now, only 22 of the 30 projects targeted by China's State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) have complied with the directive.

Manchester United trimmed Chelsea's Premier League lead to nine points with a hard-fought victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney capitalized on Gary Neville's precise cross by firing a low shot towards the near post, which took a fortuitous deflection off Richard Dunne before finding its way into the back of the net. The Red Devils doubled their advantage seven minutes later, albeit through a stroke of misfortune for Dunne, who inadvertently directed a volley past David James and into his own goal. Earlier in the match, Steve McManaman squandered City's best opportunity when he shot wide from close range during the first half. Prior to that, United struggled to create clear-cut chances against a resilient City defense, managing only a single effort on target – a Paul Scholes header that sailed harmlessly over the crossbar.

Wales must learn from England's approach to addressing waiting lists, according to the newly appointed Health Minister, Dr. Brian Gibbons. On his first full day in office, Dr. Gibbons acknowledged "big challenges" but emphasized that the "essentials" are already in place. However, Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats believe that Dr. Gibbons needs to adjust his policies. Former Health Minister Jane Hutt, whom Dr. Gibbons replaced, defended her record, pointing out that waiting times and lists only constitute 10% of the health agenda. As a former GP in Blaengwynfi, in the Upper Afan Valley, and now AM for Aberavon, Dr. Gibbons recognizes the need for NHS staff to have a period of consolidation following significant change and reform. The lengthy waiting lists in Wales has been one of the major hurdles Ms. Hutt faced during her five-and-a-half years as the Assembly's first Health Minister.

Alex Ferguson lauded Manchester United's determined display in their 1-0 victory at Aston Villa, citing it as their most challenging away game of the season. "It was an excellent contest, a thrilling end-to-end match with plenty of impressive passing," he said. "Our team showcased tremendous spirit and resilience, refusing to accept defeat. I believe this result demonstrates our strength and depth, especially considering Arsenal and Chelsea still have to visit Villa Park, where we've already secured a win." Ferguson also commended veteran players Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who entered the game after John O'Shea's injury. "Roy brought a sense of calmness and control to our midfield, something only he can provide. His presence made a significant difference."

George Michael's candid documentary, offering a glimpse into his life as a chart-topping singer, will premiere at this year's Berlin Film Festival. As part of the Panorama section, which runs from February 10th to 20th, the film will feature the artist sharing stories about his career and personal experiences, spanning from his Wham! days to current events. Michael is set to attend the festival on February 16th, where he will introduce the screening. Joining him will be director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens. Lasting 93 minutes, the film promises insightful discussions about Michael's early successes with Wham!, his solo career, and controversial topics such as his legal disputes with Sony and political views on the Iraq War and American politics.

For the first time, digital music downloads are being integrated into the primary US singles chart, as Billboard's Hot 100 chart now considers data from download sales alongside physical sales and airplay. Previously, downloads were tracked separately in Billboard's digital chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" currently holds the number two spot in the pop chart and leads the digital chart. In line with this change, download sales will soon be factored into the UK singles chart as well. Additionally, Billboard has introduced a new chart, the Pop 100, which combines airplay, digital, and physical sales data, but limits its airplay component to US radio stations playing chart music.

Anti-spam laws have dealt a significant blow to Scott Richter, the self-proclaimed "spam king" of the internet. His company, OptinRealBig, has been forced to seek bankruptcy protection due to mounting legal battles, including a high-profile lawsuit from Microsoft, which is seeking millions of dollars in damages. Despite this setback, OptinRealBig intends to continue operating while attempting to resolve its legal issues through Chapter 11 proceedings. The company's troubles began in December 2003, when it was sued by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer for sending billions of spam emails in violation of anti-spam laws. The lawsuit accused Richter and his associates of using 514 compromised network addresses in 35 countries to send unsolicited messages. As a result, OptinRealBig finds itself facing financial consequences for its role in polluting the internet with unwanted email messages.

Frank Arnesen, Tottenham's sporting director, has dismissed rumors of a personality clash between himself and former coach Jacques Santini as the reason for Santini's resignation. Despite media speculation suggesting otherwise, Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live that there was no truth to the claims. "It's absolutely untrue," he emphasized. "The only factor behind his departure was his personal issues. He confided in me recently, stating that this decision was strictly personal and didn't involve anyone else." When asked about the specific problems that led to Santini's sudden exit after just 13 games, Arnesen replied, "Jacques hasn't disclosed the details, but I believe we must respect his privacy. It's important to honor his request and refrain from prying into his personal matters."

Ireland's Six Nations Grand Slam aspirations remained intact as they secured an impressive victory over Scotland at Murrayfield. The Scots took an early 8-0 lead courtesy of a Hugo Southwell try, but Ireland fought back with tries from Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell to take control by halftime. Further tries from Denis Hickie and Ronan O'Gara, who contributed 13 points via his boot, stretched Ireland's advantage. Although Jon Petrie crossed for Scotland's second try, late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy confirmed Ireland's triumph. Following two tough away wins, Eddie O'Sullivan's team can now anticipate England's visit to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight, while Scotland will aim to gift Matt Williams his maiden Six Nations win when Italy arrive in Edinburgh, despite struggling to convert pressure into points.

Britain's economic future will be at the forefront of Labour's election campaign, Chancellor Gordon Brown has announced. Following the Cabinet's final meeting at No 10 before the anticipated election announcement, Brown emphasized that voters would recognize Labour's achievements in bringing stability and growth, and trust the party to continue doing so. Meanwhile, the Conservatives unveiled their plans to address "yob culture," while the Liberal Democrats provided further details on their proposal to replace council tax. In a related development, the Archbishop of Canterbury penned an open letter to all three parties, urging them not to resort to fear-mongering tactics during the election campaign. Specifically, he cautioned against using terrorism, asylum, and crime as tools to scare voters into supporting one party over another.

Eight Irish athletes, including defending champion Paul Brizzel, will compete in the AAA's Championships in Sheffield this weekend as they vie for spots in the European Indoor Championships. Notably absent from the list are US-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll, who have already secured their places in the European team. Brizzel will aim to defend his 200m title in the British trials, while James McIlroy seeks to solidify his position in the British team for Madrid by claiming the 800m title. With his exceptional performance on the European circuit in recent weeks, McIlroy is a strong contender for a spot in Madrid and is currently ranked among the fastest 800m runners globally. Mark Carroll, who confirmed his participation in the European Championships alongside Cragg earlier this week, holds third place in the world 3000m rankings, behind Cragg who sits atop the leaderboard.

Jason Robinson, a former rugby league international who switched codes in 2000, aims to achieve dual code success as England's rugby union captain when they face Australia on Saturday. The first match kicks off at 14:30 GMT, where Robinson will lead his side against Australia at Twickenham. Later that day, Great Britain's rugby league team will meet Australia in the Tri-Nations Tournament final at Elland Road, with a scheduled start time of 18:15 GMT. According to Robinson, defeating the Australians in both matches would be a remarkable feat, particularly for league. A victory for England would mark their third consecutive autumn international win, following previous triumphs over Canada and South Africa, and serve as revenge for June's 51-15 defeat to the Wallabies. Moreover, Great Britain could snap a 34-year losing streak against Australia with a win at Elland Road.

Beware of a fraudulent website claiming to collect donations for tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate as it replicates an outdated version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee (DEC) webpage. However, DEC has no affiliation with this bogus site and has alerted law enforcement authorities. This recent scam joins a growing list exploiting public generosity in response to the devastating tsunami. A spam email containing the website link is currently making rounds, sporting a questionable subject line - "Urgent Tsunami Earthquake Appeal" - and littered with grammatical errors and misspellings typical of phishing attempts.

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming to substantially enhance nationwide coverage over the next decade. Local, Arab, and foreign companies are welcome to participate, as announced by the Ministry of Communications. The successful bidder will collaborate with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to establish and operate a fixed-line phone network offering voice, fax, and internet services. With a current "very low" penetration rate of around 4.5%, the ministry aspires to reach a target of 25% within ten years. Additionally, they seek to create a dynamic and rapidly evolving telecommunications sector. Interested parties can find details of the bidding and tender process on the ministry's website starting from February 9th, with a planned roadshow for investors taking place in Amman, Jordan.

According to a two-year study, there has been a significant increase in older individuals and women taking responsibility for securing their home computers against malevolent online threats. The study, conducted by preventon, a net security firm, revealed that the number of women purchasing programs to protect their PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks grew by 11.2% annually between 2002 and 2004. These findings suggest that security messages are effectively reaching a diverse group of internet users. Notably, 40% of those investing in home net security solutions are retired, with a 13.2% average increase in the past three years. Interestingly, retired women (53%) are more likely to purchase security software than retired men. This trend reflects both the shifting stereotypes and demographics of web users and the growing recognition of the heightened risks associated with high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasts have emerged as a DIY radio revolution, enabled by devices like Apple iPods and other digital music players that can store up to 10,000 songs. However, instead of just storing music, these devices are now filled with audio content created by a diverse array of producers. This phenomenon is known as podcasting, championed by Adam Curry, a former MTV host and VJ. Despite its name, podcasting doesn't require an iPod; anyone can create and listen to podcasts using a mic, PC, and editing software. Podcasters produce internet-based radio shows from the comfort of their homes, which they then upload to the web for others to download and enjoy for free.

Andrea Levy's novel "Small Island" has won the Whitbread Novel of the Year Award, making her the front-runner for the coveted Whitbread Book of the Year title. Levy beat out stiff competition from Alan Hollinghurst's Man Booker Prize-winning novel "The Line of Beauty." In addition, Geraldine McCaughrean took home the Children's Fiction Award for the third time for her work "Not the End of the World." The winners of each category are now in contention for the top honor, which comes with a £25,000 prize. A distinguished panel of judges, featuring Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on January 25th to select the overall winner. That same evening, William Hill, a prominent bookmaker, has installed London-based Levy's novel as the 6/4 favorite to emerge victorious.

Yukos will return to a US court on Wednesday to pursue sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the obscure firm that acquired its primary asset. Yukos plans to file a lawsuit against Baikal and other parties involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas, seeking $20 billion in damages. Following the Russian government's disregard for a US court order that blocked the sale, Yukos' legal team in the US will endeavor to have Baikal's assets frozen. The exact nature and motivations behind Baikal's purchase of the unit remain shrouded in mystery, although Russian media outlets have speculated that the company, which purchased Yuganskneftegas' production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion rubles, £4.8 billion) at a controversial auction, has close ties to Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-largest oil producer.

Hearts sealed their Scottish Cup quarter-final victory against Livingston with two early goals, both scored within the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller opened the scoring 60 seconds into the match, rising above Colin Meldrum to head Jamie McAllister's precise free kick into the net. McAllister then added the second himself, meeting Saul Mikoliunas' pinpoint cross at the back post to give Hearts a commanding lead. Although Craig Easton pulled one back for Livingston with an hour played, Hearts comfortably held on for the win. The hosts' dominant start was set in motion by Gus Bahoken's foul on Miller 35 yards from goal, which led to McAllister floating a well-placed free kick into the Livingston box. Miller capitalized on the resulting confusion among the visiting defense, outjumping them to loop a header from 10 yards over Meldrum. Just 10 minutes later, Mikoliunas burst down the right flank before delivering a perfectly weighted cross to the back post, where McAllister arrived unmarked to nod past Meldrum and secure Hearts' convincing advantage.

Sun Microsystems has introduced a pay-as-you-go service that enables clients who require substantial computing power to rent it hourly. Dubbed Sun Grid, the offering charges users $1 (53p) per hour for access to processing and storage capabilities maintained by Sun. This innovative approach to computing, referred to as grid computing, is gaining traction within the industry, with Sun drawing parallels between its potential growth and the historical development of essential utilities like electricity and water. During a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California, Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz posed the question, "Why invest in building your own grid when you can tap into ours for just $1 an hour?"

Scotland's Justice Minister, Cathy Jamieson, has issued a stern warning to bigoted soccer fans, threatening to ban them from matches as part of the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. Exclusion orders are among several measures being considered to combat this problem, which has long plagued Old Firm matches between Celtic and Rangers. While praising the clubs for their efforts to address the issue, Jamieson emphasized that eradicating sectarian abuse remains a top priority. Her comments come ahead of the upcoming Scottish Cup clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday, where tensions are expected to run high. In a bid to tackle the problem, Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell recently met with supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss possible solutions.

Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth graced the red carpet at London's Leicester Square on Thursday for the British premiere of their new film, Beyond the Sea. The movie, which Spacey wrote, directed, and starred in, tells the story of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. Inspired by Darin's life, Spacey, 45, pays tribute to the singer's legacy, performing all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack himself. Bosworth, 21, portrays Darin's wife, Hollywood actress Sandra Dee, and confesses that she had little knowledge of Darin prior to the project, but has since become a big admirer. She attended the event alongside her British beau, Orlando Bloom.
