The traditional home phone may be facing extinction as mobile phones continue to gain popularity. A recent study conducted by Nokia found that an increasing number of people are relying solely on their mobile devices for all their calling needs. In fact, over 45 million individuals in countries like the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea have abandoned their landlines altogether. While cost remains a significant factor, with many users citing lower call charges as the reason for keeping their fixed lines, the majority of respondents believe that the future of communication lies in mobile technology. Interestingly, the Nokia-sponsored research revealed distinct patterns in usage habits between fixed and mobile phones. Longer conversations tend to occur on home phones, whereas mobile calls are generally shorter and often made between friends or within social circles. Notably, 69% of UK participants stated that they prefer their fixed phones due to cheaper rates compared to mobile services.

Jürgen Melzer stunned second-seeded Andre Agassi in the quarterfinals of the SAP Open, handing him a decisive defeat, 6-3, 6-1. Agassi struggled against Melzer's clever use of drop shots throughout the match in San Jose. Meanwhile, defending champion and top seed Andy Roddick fought back to overcome Sweden's Thomas Enqvist in a thrilling three-setter, winning 3-6, 7-6 (8-6), 7-5. In other matches, unseeded Cyril Saulnier upset fourth-seeded Vincent Spadea, 6-2, 6-4, while Tommy Haas edged past eighth-seeded Max Mirnyi, 6-7 (2-7), 7-6 (7-3), 6-2. With this victory, Melzer has now defeated Agassi twice in their three encounters. "I had a solid game plan and executed it flawlessly," Melzer said. "It's always challenging to face Andre. I aimed to dictate the pace and prevent him from imposing his style, making me run around the court endlessly."

A group of MPs has intensified pressure on Tony Blair to reform the House of Lords by publishing a comprehensive plan for change. The cross-party group has put forth a draft bill that proposes a smaller second chamber with 70% of its members elected. Attempts at reform have been stalled since 1999, when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. However, the group is confident that it can garner support for eliminating the remaining 92 hereditaries. The government previously delayed plans to remove these peers due to concerns about facing opposition from the Lords. Tony Blair maintains that achieving consensus on reforms is crucial. There have been hints that Labour's manifesto might include proposals to modify the Lords' powers.

Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at the European Indoor Championships next week, despite feeling somewhat disappointed with his solid debut performance on the international circuit. At the Jose M Cagigal Memorial Meeting in Madrid, the 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles, which featured a star-studded field. Although he didn't achieve the podium finish he had hoped for, Scott views the experience as a valuable learning opportunity and hasn't given up on his medal aspirations. The East Kilbride athlete acknowledged that the competition served as a stepping stone for his growth, saying, "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week." The eventual winner of the race was Spain's Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the national record, followed closely by Sweden's Robert Kronberg in second place, and Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. While Scott felt a tad disappointed with his finals performance – running 0.04 seconds slower than his heat time of 7.64 seconds – he remains focused and determined to excel at the upcoming championship.

A Georgia woman is suing Hewlett Packard (HP) alleging that the company's printer ink cartridges are designed to expire on a specific date, regardless of their actual ink level. According to the lawsuit, a chip embedded in the cartridge misleads the printer into thinking it needs refilling, even when it doesn't. The legal action seeks to represent all US residents who have purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the global leader in printer sales, declined to comment on the matter. Interestingly, HP's ink cartridges utilize chip technology to detect low ink levels and alert users when it's time to replace them. However, the lawsuit asserts that these same chips can prematurely render the cartridges useless, supposedly to boost sales of replacement cartridges.

Virgin Radio is set to revolutionize the way we consume radio content, announcing plans to become the world's first station to broadcast via 3G mobile phones. In collaboration with technology partner Sydus, Virgin Radio will be accessible on select 2G and high-speed 3G networks, allowing listeners to tune in on-the-go. By later this year, users will be able to download software from the Virgin Radio website, enabling them to enjoy the service seamlessly. James Cridland, Head of New Media at Virgin Radio, expressed his excitement, stating, "This development places radio at the forefront of the 3G revolution." Following the launch, two additional digital stations - Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove - will join the lineup, further expanding the reach of Virgin Radio's innovative offering. According to Cridland, the application will empower anyone, regardless of location, to enjoy Virgin Radio with just their smartphone, cementing the brand's commitment to staying ahead of the curve in the rapidly evolving world of radio broadcasting.

Roxy Music is set to perform at the Isle of Wight Festival in June, joined by Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. The iconic band, known for their unique blend of art rock and glam, will take the stage on Saturday night, featuring original members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzanera, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson. This highly anticipated performance comes as the band works on new material, their first release since Avalon in 1982. Formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, Roxy Music quickly gained popularity with hits like "Virginia Plain" (1972), "Street Life," "Love is the Drug," and their memorable cover of John Lennon's "Jealous Guy" (1981).

Four Six Nations captains, including Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll, have been selected for the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid Match on March 5th. Joining O'Driscoll are France's Fabien Pelous, Scotland's Gordon Bulloch, and Italy's Marco Bortolami. The Northern team will be coached by Sir Clive Woodward, who will face off against Rod MacQueen's Southern Hemisphere team at Twickenham Stadium in a tsunami fund-raising match. Woodward expressed his excitement about working with such exceptional players, which will also provide him with an opportunity to assess potential British and Irish Lions touring party members before their summer visit to New Zealand. He anticipates a thrilling spectacle come match day.

The Independent Spirit Awards have been swept by "Sideways," a comedy that received six nods and won every category it was nominated for. Alexander Payne won Best Director and Best Screenplay, alongside his co-writer Jim Taylor. Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen, the film's stars, respectively, took home Acting honors. With five Academy Award nominations, "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's ceremony. Now in its 20th year, the Spirits recognize films produced outside the mainstream studio system and precede the Oscars by a day. Other victors include Catalina Sandino Moreno, who earned Best Actress for her portrayal of a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also up for an Oscar in the same category. Joshua Marston claimed the prize for Best First Screenplay for "Maria Full of Grace."

Prince was named the top music earner by Rolling Stone magazine in 2004, outranking popular artists like Madonna and Elton John. With earnings of $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, albums, and publishing sales, Prince's successful Musicology Tour and album release helped him secure the top spot. Madonna followed closely behind, earning $54.9 million (£29.5 million) through her Global Re-Invention Tour. Simon and Garfunkel, who reunited for a comeback tour, earned $24.9 million (£13.4 million), placing them at number ten on the list. According to Rolling Stone, Prince's return to center stage after a decade of relative obscurity paid off, as his 2004 tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales alone, and his latest album, Musicology, sold over 1.9 million copies.

1. Instead of starting with a vague statement like "Blue beat u2 to top France honour," consider beginning with a more specific and attention-grabbing sentence, such as "Irish rock band U2 was honored at France's NRJ Music Awards, but they didn't take home the top prize."
2. In the second sentence, use parallel structure to emphasize the contrast between U2's achievement and Blue's victory. For example: "U2 received a special achievement prize at the NRJ Music Awards, while Boy Band Blue won the International Group Award."
3. To improve readability, break up long sentences into shorter ones. For instance, instead of combining all the information about Maroon 5 in one sentence, separate it into two simpler sentences: "US band Maroon 5 was named Best New International Artist. They also took home the Best International Song title for 'This Love.'"
4. Use active voice instead of passive voice where possible. For example, instead of saying "The international male and female prizes went to Usher and Avril Lavigne respectively," say "Usher and Avril Lavigne won the International Male and Female Prizes."
5. Consider adding transitions to connect ideas within the paragraph. For example, you could start the paragraph with a transition like "The NRJ Music Awards celebrated the best in music, with Irish rock band U2 among those honored."
6. Finally, proofread carefully to catch any errors in spelling, grammar, or punctuation. For example, "Côte d'Azur" should have an accented "e" in "Cannes".

Wal-mart is fighting back against its critics with a national advertising campaign aimed at setting the record straight about its products and corporate practices. In response to growing scrutiny, the retail giant has taken out over 100 full-page ads in major newspapers, including The Wall Street Journal. Through an open letter from President Lee Scott, Wal-mart is attempting to address criticisms regarding its pay scales, benefits packages, and career advancement opportunities. Separately, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is also launching a campaign to counter what it calls "false" claims about its popular antidepressant Prozac. In his letter, Scott emphasizes the need for the public to hear the unvarnished truth about Wal-mart, stating, "There are plenty of urban legends circulating about our company, but facts are facts."

The Conservatives have proposed a plan to allow local communities to elect their own area police commissioner, a move that would replace the current "inconspicuous" police authorities, according to party leader Michael Howard. While the new role would not supersede the job of a chief constable, critics from the Liberal Democrats and Labour have expressed concerns that it could lead to extremist groups running policing. In response, Jan Berry, Chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales, emphasized the importance of maintaining operational independence for law enforcement. She cautioned that the proposal risked allowing those with radical political views to dictate policing decisions, jeopardizing public safety.

The UK's Conservative Party has proposed introducing health checks for immigrants if they win the upcoming general election. Under their plan, individuals from outside the EU who intend to reside and work in Britain for at least six months and hail from countries with high rates of tuberculosis (TB) will be required to undergo a chest X-ray and additional tests as necessary. Those seeking to remain in the country for over a year will need to complete a comprehensive medical examination covering TB, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB diagnosis would result in automatic denial of visa applications, while other conditions would be assessed on a case-by-case basis.

The thrilling Six Nations match between Wales and France in Paris has sparked hope among Welsh fans that their team might achieve its first Grand Slam victory since 1978. The game left rugby enthusiasts in awe, with Welsh legend Mervyn Davies, who was part of two Grand Slam-winning teams in the 1970s, praising it as one of the greatest displays in the past three decades. Martyn Williams, who scored two tries for Wales, described it as "one of the most surreal games I've ever played in." Meanwhile, Bernard Laporte, the defeated French coach, couldn't help but notice the stark contrast between his team's performance and Wales', remarking, "There was a French half and there was a Welsh half."

Doves have soared to the top of the UK album chart with their latest release, Some Cities, replacing Scissor Sisters at the summit. The trio's achievement comes after their single Black and White Town peaked at number six. Nelly's Over and Over, featuring Tim McGraw, has claimed the number one spot on the singles chart, pushing aside previous chart-topper Girls Aloud. Akon and Kaiser Chiefs also make appearances in the top ten with their respective singles Locked Up and Oh My God, while Futureheads and Usher round out the list. Notably, Elvis Presley's re-released track (Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame debuted at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's Wake Me Up.

Davies, who starred in Wales' RBS Six Nations victory over England on Saturday, is expected to remain with English club Gloucester despite reported interest from Neath-Swansea Ospreys. According to BBC Wales, the Ospreys have expressed interest in the 32-year-old hooker, but he prefers to stay put. Davies is currently on a one-year contract with Gloucester, but his impressive performance for the Zurich Premiership side is likely to result in a new deal next season. Following the disbandment of the Celtic Warriors region, Davies found himself without a professional contract and had to settle for a semi-pro arrangement with Neath RFC. He later joined Gloucester after admitting that he felt mistreated by the Welsh Rugby Union and unhappy with his situation at the Ospreys, for whom he played on loan during the 2004-05 season.

Cabinet discontent regarding the allocation of Whitehall funds to curb council tax increases has been acknowledged by Local Government Minister Nick Raynsford. In last Thursday's pre-budget report, Chancellor Gordon Brown redirected £512 million from central to local government budgets. Raynsford confirmed that he had engaged in open discussions with colleagues about the plan but emphasized the need for local authorities to provide quality services while keeping council tax hikes under 5% in the upcoming financial year, which coincides with the general election. He stressed that most central government departments have a vested interest in efficient local governance.

Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin, an Israeli club, has turned its attention to Africa for talent, signing four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro. This development comes as the team prepares to make history as the first Arab side to compete in European football, facing Newcastle United in the UEFA Cup's first round. Murambadoro, who gained recognition during the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, played a crucial role in Bnei Sakhnin's 6-1 victory over Albania's Partizani Tirana in the previous round. After a brief stint with South African club Hellenic, Murambadoro joined Bnei Sakhnin, which is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. The club has a strong commitment to fostering peace and cooperation within Israel and has won the Israeli Cup title in the previous season.

Cutting the legal drink-drive limit by a third could save more lives than initially estimated, according to a new report. Researchers at University College London found that reducing the limit from 80mg to 50mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood would annually save 65 lives, which is higher than the 50 lives projected in a 1998 Department of Transport document. The study, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, also suggests that such a change would result in 230 fewer serious injuries on UK roads each year, yielding cost savings of £119 million. These findings are being presented to MPs as they prepare to vote on the Government's Road Safety Bill, which currently does not include modifications to the drink-drive limit.

This paper introduces a millimeter-scale CMOS 64x64 single charged particle radiation detector system designed for external beam cancer radiotherapy. The system features a 1x1 micrometer squared diode that measures energy deposition by individual charged particles in the depletion region, while the array design offers a spacious detection area of 512x512 micrometers squared. Unlike traditional systems that sense voltage drops caused by radiation, the proposed design measures pulse width – the time required for the voltage to return to its baseline. This approach eliminates the need for bulky and power-intensive analog-to-digital converters. Fabricated using TSMC 65nm LP CMOS technology, a prototype ASIC consumes an average static power of merely 0.535 milliwatts at 1.2 volts for both analog and digital components. In a successful clinical trial utilizing a 67.5 MeV proton beam, the system demonstrated its full capabilities.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been demonstrated to minimize the negative effects of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, assuming that AVs will readily submit to external control by a central authority is impractical. To address this challenge, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme that encourages AVs to adopt system-optimal (SO) routing by offering toll savings, while simultaneously imposing a congestion charge on user-equilibrium (UE) seeking AVs and human-driven vehicles (HVs). Our approach involves formulating the problem as a bi-level optimization, where dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, and the lower level employs a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model that considers a diverse fleet of AVs and HVs.

Recent advances in optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled the preparation of macroscopic mechanical oscillators in their quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This breakthrough has not only brought large-scale objects into the realm of quantum behavior but also inspired ideas for utilizing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing and communication, as well as precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the inherently linear interaction between motion and light or electricity restricts access to a broader range of quantum states of motion, including cat states and energy squeezed states. Early proposals in optomechanics suggested that introducing strong quadratic coupling of motion to light could overcome this limitation. While experiments have demonstrated quadratically coupled optomechanical systems, they have yet to achieve nonclassical states of motion.

Online product reviews help customers make informed purchase decisions. However, these evaluations can be manipulated through fake reviews created by skilled spammers who employ sophisticated and ever-evolving tactics to evade detection. The constantly changing nature of these strategies makes them difficult to pinpoint, as they vary over time, differ among spammers, and often remain undetected. Moreover, while most existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, this approach does not align with the primary objective of preserving the credibility of product evaluations. To overcome these challenges, we devise a minimax game where spammers and spam detectors engage in a strategic competition focused on practical goals rather than mere detection precision. By analyzing the Nash equilibria of the game, we develop robust detectors that are immune to various detection strategies, ensuring the integrity of online product reviews.

We have developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra-high fidelity (UHF) population transfer on a 3-level quantum system in a lambda configuration. Our approach utilizes the Lewis-Riesenfeld (L-R) method to generate a family of solutions that lead to exact transfer, with the added benefit of following a single dynamical mode of the L-R invariant. From this family, we have identified a tracking solution with a single parameter that simultaneously controls the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. To quantify the robustness of UHF transfers, we define a metric as the minimum percentile deviation in pulse areas required for the infidelity to exceed $10^{-4}$. Our analysis reveals that the robustness of our shaped pulses outperforms that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we investigate the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function for Gaussian mixture models with a variable number of components. Nonconvexity gives rise to multiple local minima, which may not be globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. Our findings reveal that all local minima possess a common structural feature: they involve a non-overlapping combination of fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components. This partial identification of component centers holds for mixtures satisfying a specific separation condition, and remains valid regardless of whether the number of components is over- or underspecified. Notably, for Gaussian mixtures with three components, our results provide sharper scalings with respect to the inter-component separation.

We explore the relationship between two constructions of the mirror partner for a Calabi-Yau orbifold. Specifically, we consider a Calabi-Yau orbifold defined as a quotient of a hypersurface $x_m$ in a weighted projective space by a suitable subgroup $g$ of its phase symmetries. This orbifold is cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial $w_m$. Our focus is on the connection between two different approaches to constructing the mirror partner: the Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction and the Batyrev construction. The BHK construction employs another weighted projective space and forms the quotient of a new hypersurface $x_{m^t}$ within it by some dual group $g^t$. On the other hand, the Batyrev construction builds the mirror partner as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the polytope associated with the original Calabi-Yau orbifold. By providing a straightforward piece of evidence, we demonstrate the equivalence of these two constructions.

This study generalized existing models of the human gait from the literature, such as Keller and Kocksheniev's models, to develop a novel approach. Our hybrid model combines a metabolic energy minimization strategy within a racing process, featuring a non-linear description of the mass center's libration motion. This innovative approach aims to accurately replicate the walk-run transition. Experimental findings at various speed regimes suggest that the perimeter of the mass center's trajectory plays a significant role in characterizing this dynamic. To obtain these results, we collaborated with the Biomedical Engineering Research Group, Basic Sciences, and Laboratories at Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia, employing a rigorous experimental protocol.

We introduce a novel mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that accurately resolves close encounters. Our method is founded on a time regularization technique that preserves the stability attributes of symplectic integrators while adaptively decreasing the effective step size during planetary encounters. By employing a high-order MVS scheme, we can integrate with substantial time steps in regions unaffected by close encounters. Our algorithm efficiently handles near-collisions (with a mutual separation of a few percent of the physical radius) utilizing the same time step as in weakly perturbed scenarios, such as the solar system. In a comprehensive analysis, we demonstrate the long-term behavior of our method on systems consisting of six super-Earths undergoing intense scattering over 50 kyr. Our findings indicate that, compared to hybrid approaches like Mercury, our algorithm achieves superior energy conservation at an equal computational cost.

Entanglement is a crucial resource for quantum information processing. One widely used method for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, which guarantees a positive measurement outcome for all separable states and can produce a negative result for certain entangled states. However, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is a significant challenge due to the exponential increase in Hilbert space dimension with respect to the number of parties involved. For instance, the most robust witness scheme for $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states necessitates $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to half a unit of white noise. By contrast, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states requires only two local measurements and can withstand up to one-third of a unit of white noise.

In general relativity, the kerr spacetime represents the unique stationary solution for an isolated black hole, characterized by a distinctive multipolar structure determined solely by its mass and spin. By developing a comprehensive method to extract multipole moments from arbitrary stationary spacetimes, we investigate a broad range of horizonless microstate geometries that may depart from the symmetries of the kerr metric. These microstates offer a means to empirically constrain fuzzball models through their richer multipolar structure. Our numerics reveal that the absolute values of multipole moments for these microstates generally exceed those of a kerr black hole with comparable mass and spin. Although current observations of black-hole candidates provide limited constraints on fuzzballs via quadrupole moment measurements, forthcoming high-precision data from gravitational-wave detectors like LISA will significantly tighten these limits by several orders of magnitude, particularly for extreme mass-ratio inspirals.

In various fields, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks, reasoning about graph evolution over time poses significant challenges. We focus on a common scenario where edge types include brief interactions, such as messaging, and long-term structural connections, like friendships. While long-term edges are typically defined by humans, they can be costly to establish and may not suit the specific requirements of the subsequent task. Our proposed approach leverages temporal point processes and variational autoencoders to develop a model that learns to assign temporal attention between nodes by analyzing their communication patterns. By allowing the temporal attention mechanism to drive feature propagation between nodes, our method offers greater adaptability while sidestepping the limitations of human-defined edges.

Researchers have observed thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW), consisting of two parallel nanobeams separated by a 240 nm vacuum gap. To investigate the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe, models have been developed and validated for probe frequencies both far from and near the dielectric band edge. As the PCW has been designed for near-field atom trapping, this study lays the groundwork for assessing potential detrimental effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near PCW surfaces. Ultimately, the goal is to establish robust links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons propagating in the guided modes of the PCW, paving the way for quantum optomechanics involving atoms, photons, and phonons.

We introduce natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. Specifically, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. These splittings are of great interest in equivariant stable homotopy theory, as they enable us to deduce the regularity of certain Euler classes associated with the tautological representations of $O(n)$ and $U(n)$ from the splittings of the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{MO}$ and $\mathbf{MU}$. Moreover, the splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences break up into shorter exact sequences, providing valuable insight into the structure of these groups.

Baryonic feedback effects significantly suppress the weak lensing angular power spectrum on smaller scales. However, the shape and amplitude of this suppression remain poorly constrained, posing substantial uncertainties for forthcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like Euclid and LSST. In this initial paper of a two-part series, we utilize simulations to create a Euclid-like tomographic mock dataset encompassing the cosmic shear power spectrum and its associated covariance matrix, both of which have been adjusted for baryonic impacts using Schneider et al.'s (2019) baryonification technique. Additionally, we develop an emulator to rapidly generate predictions of the baryonic power suppression, permitting us to perform a likelihood inference analysis for a standard λCDM cosmology involving both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those captured in child-centered recordings, pose significant challenges for speech processing. Despite these difficulties, developing models capable of handling such variability is crucial for language acquisition studies, which aim to quantify and assess the quality of speech that children hear and produce, as well as for early detection and monitoring of interventions. In this paper, we introduce our methodology for creating an open-source neural network that classifies audio segments into four distinct categories: vocalizations made by the recorded child, vocalizations made by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. To achieve this, we compiled a diverse collection of child-centered corpora, totaling 260 hours of recordings and covering ten languages.

Density-based clustering hinges on the notion of connecting groupings to distinct aspects of the underlying probability distribution of the data. By invoking a genuine, though unobserved, population structure, we can cast the clustering problem within a conventional inferential framework, where the concept of optimal clusterization is defined as the segmentation generated by the authentic density function. This approach's nonparametric formulation, dubbed modal clustering, establishes a relationship between the groups and the attractor regions of the density modes. To operationalize modal clustering, a nonparametric density estimate is necessary, and selecting the appropriate amount of smoothing, which influences the density's shape and potentially the modal configuration, is critical in determining the ultimate partition. Our work tackles the challenge of density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic standpoint.

The Large Hadron Collider (LHC) is capable of probing the tails of diboson production, which are sensitive to the interplay between the Standard Model and higher-dimension operators that describe the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for diboson scattering amplitudes pose an obstacle to the straightforward interference contributions of dimension-six operators, resulting in the cancellation of the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction. By carefully measuring the azimuthal decay angles, the interference can be restored, regaining sensitivity to the supposedly non-interfering operators. We thoroughly investigate these signatures and discover that the Effective Field Theory (EFT) uncertainties related to higher-dimensional operators can be effectively suppressed using an asymmetry variable that is generated solely by the non-interfering operators. Consequently, the impact of higher-dimensional, interfering operators is downgraded to the level of statistical errors in this observable.

In the health and social sciences, drawing causal inferences from observational data is a common aim of many data analyses. Yet, traditional academic statistics have often discouraged data analyses with a causal focus. The emergence of the term "data science" presents an opportune moment to reconceptualize data analysis in a way that seamlessly incorporates causal inference from observational data. Building on previous work, we categorize the scientific contributions of data science into three task categories: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (encompassing causal inference). Clearly defining these data science tasks allows for a more informed discussion of the requisite data, assumptions, and analytics needed to achieve each one successfully. Notably, we contend that failing to properly acknowledge the significance of subject-matter expertise in data analysis has been a major source of confusion regarding data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) requires the presence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. While it's commonly believed that these particles are necessary to ensure instability or marginal stability of extremal black holes, it's unclear what goes awry if they don't exist. This note demonstrates that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in anti-de Sitter space (AdS), the exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with established quantum information theorems regarding entanglement entropy. To resolve this tension, we need a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the conventional statement at weak coupling. Our argument applies generally, without reliance on supersymmetry or specific ultraviolet completions, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can exhibit unconventional superconductivity at high critical temperatures remains a significant challenge in condensed matter physics. To address this problem, researchers have turned to ultracold 2D Fermi gases as clean and controllable model systems, which allow for the investigation of the interplay between strong interactions and reduced dimensionality. Although these systems show promise, direct evidence of superfluidity has been lacking. In our work, we provide such evidence by demonstrating superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas using a periodic potential sweep technique. By measuring the critical velocity (v_c) below which there is no dissipation, we observe a maximum in the crossover region between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity as a function of interaction strength. Our results position ultracold Fermi gases as a valuable platform for exploring the impact of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

Ordinary differential equations (ODEs) are widely employed across various fields, including climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering, due to their intuitive ability to model complex phenomena. However, the lack of analytical solutions for ODEs often hinders the estimation of model parameters from data, particularly when dealing with models possessing numerous variables and parameters. To address this challenge, we propose a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that exhibits both efficiency and accuracy, even when applied to models with a large number of parameters. Our approach involves approximating an ODE model using a state-space model derived from the equations of a numerical solver. By doing so, we circumvent the need for computing the entire numerical solution in the likelihood function, thereby enabling rapid estimation. The posterior distribution is obtained through a Variational Bayes method, specifically the Approximate Riemannian Conjugate Gradient Method (Honkela et al.).

We investigate the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in NSN junctions formed by a Weyl semimetal (WSM) in contact with an $s$-wave superconductor. Our study reveals that the differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes exhibit a strong dependence on the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. Notably, we discover the impact of a chiral chemical potential, which arises from an electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the transport characteristics of the junction. Furthermore, we observe a remarkable phenomenon where Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions acquire a net spin polarization. This spin polarization is found to be opposite in the two WSM regions and shows a high sensitivity to both the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Titanium ion implantation into alumina has proven to be an efficient and controlled method for modifying the surface electrical conductivity of ceramics, with various applications benefiting from this technique. Notably, it enables the gradual reduction of voltage drops across high-voltage insulators, thereby enhancing their maximum operational voltage without triggering surface flashovers. Although concerns exist regarding the long-term stability of the conductivity induced by implantation, particularly when using readily oxidizable metals like titanium, our investigation reveals promising results. Our findings show that while there was an initial decline of around 40% in the first few weeks post-implantation, the conductivity exhibits a negligible decrease of approximately 10% over the subsequent year.

We present a novel conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, inspired by the concept of hidden local symmetry. Notably, the associated charge matches the Skyrmion charge for all smooth configurations. Moreover, we identify singular configurations that can be associated with N_F = 1 baryons, which are charged under the newly proposed symmetry. These vector mesons play a crucial role in the formation of the Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the N_F = 1 baryon. We suggest that this current serves as the appropriate effective representation of the baryon current at low energies. Our proposal offers a harmonious framework for understanding both types of baryons and enables a seamless transformation between them. Furthermore, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be interpreted as a consequence of Seiberg-like dualities between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions presents an intriguing opportunity to integrate anomalous Hall and Josephson physics into a single device. In our theoretical study, we investigate how the superposition of these two effects affects the transport properties of superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions. By considering transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface, we observe the emergence of significant transverse Hall supercurrents, which we refer to as anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. Building upon the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, initially developed to quantify conventional (tunneling) Josephson current flows, we generalized it to assess the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes can be widely tuned via the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. Notably, well-localized subgap bound states manifest around the interface, serving as a distinctive spectroscopic signature of Josephson junctions.

According to Jiménez (J. Fluid Mech., 2020), dipoles play a crucial role in the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence, comparable to that of individual vortex cores. It has been discovered that the kinetic energy of this flow is primarily carried by elongated streams composed of concatenated dipoles. The vortices segregate into two distinct families: smaller, rapidly moving cores and larger, slower-moving ones that can be characterized as a "frozen" crystal. The kinematics of these families differ significantly, with only the former exhibiting self-similarity. The latter family contributes the majority of the flow's kinetic energy and forms the dipoles and streams. Mechanisms behind the growth of this slow component are also explored.

Continuous-time quantum walks have emerged as a valuable framework for developing various quantum algorithms. The running time of these algorithms is often gauged by the quantum hitting time, which represents the time taken by the quantum walk to locate a vertex of interest with high likelihood. In this article, we present enhanced upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to multiple quantum algorithms based on continuous-time quantum walks. Our techniques are demonstrated through improvements to the glued-trees problem, where we reduce the hitting time upper bound from $O(n^5)$ to $O(n^2 \log n)$, and significantly enhance the dependence on precision of Chakraborty et al.'s continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm for finding a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be categorized into two formation mechanisms: dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs. Previously, dry EMRIs, also known as "loss-cone" EMRIs, were thought to be the primary source for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna. These occur mainly through multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. However, we bring attention to another formation channel: wet EMRIs, which are facilitated by the accretion flow surrounding accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). The accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially moving on inclined orbits and drives them to migrate towards the MBH, significantly enhancing the formation rate of EMRIs in these galaxies by several orders of magnitude.

When a new user joins a website, we often lack information about them, including their interactions with items, user profiles, and social connections with others. Despite this, we aim to engage these new users immediately, encouraging them to remain on the platform and become active members. This challenge belongs to the new user cold-start category and is vital for a company's growth and success. Previous solutions for user cold-start recommendation either demand extra effort from users, like interviews, or rely on supplementary data, such as demographics, location, and social networks. However, users may resist participating in interviews, and cold-start users typically lack accessible side information.

Deep learning has effectively addressed numerous issues beyond the capabilities of heuristic algorithms. Its application in wireless communications has also yielded significant successes, despite the fact that existing radio systems are generally well-understood and optimal algorithms are available for various tasks. However, while some progress has been made by focusing on individual components of a receiver, a more effective strategy is to jointly learn the entire receiver system. Unfortunately, this often leads to a complex nonlinear problem that makes it difficult to obtain an optimal solution. To address this challenge, we introduce deeprx, a deep fully convolutional neural network that efficiently executes the complete receiver pipeline – from frequency domain signal streams to unencoded bits – in a 5G-compliant manner. By carefully designing the input of the convolutional neural network using both data and pilot symbols, we ensure precise channel estimation, further enhancing the performance of our proposed approach.

Mutation-based fuzzing commonly employs an initial collection of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) as the foundation for generating new inputs through mutation. However, a large corpus of potential seeds can result in redundant fuzzing efforts, as thousands of similar inputs may be explored. To overcome this limitation, fuzzers are often equipped with distillation tools (such as afl-cmin) that identify the minimal subset of seeds capable of triggering the same breadth of instrumentation data points as the entire corpus. By reducing the number and total size of seeds, fuzzing efficiency can be significantly enhanced, which we investigate systematically. Our study presents the outcomes of 34+ cpu-years of fuzzing using five distinct distillation techniques to evaluate their effectiveness in discovering bugs in real-world software.

In this study, we examine multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observability. These systems can be grouped into multiple subgroups, wherein the agents within each subgroup share identical (isomorphic) state transition structures and can hence be represented using a single template. Leveraging this template, we design a scalable supervisor that exhibits negligible growth in state size and computational complexity when the number of agents increases. Notably, the scalable supervisor remains unaffected by additions or removals of agents from the system, obviating the need for recomputation. By extending our previous findings, we propose necessary and sufficient conditions for both safety and maximal permissiveness of the scalable least restrictive supervisor at the template level. To demonstrate the efficacy of our approach, we provide an illustrative example of scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations play a crucial role in multimedia forensics. To estimate ENF efficiently, we introduce a novel approach that leverages temporal windowing based on the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. Our method exploits the Toeplitz structure of the covariance matrix through a Gohberg-Semencul factorization, enabling the use of non-rectangular temporal windows for the first time in ENF estimation. Additionally, we utilize Krylov matrices for efficient matrix inversions. Our approach outperforms existing methods in terms of accuracy and time complexity, as demonstrated by experiments using power recordings with a short time window of $1$ second and speech recordings.

The direpack package offers a comprehensive collection of contemporary statistical dimension reduction techniques, seamlessly integrated into the Python ecosystem. This suite of methods encompasses three main categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M estimators for dimension reduction. In addition, the package provides regularized regression estimators built upon these lower-dimensional spaces, spanning from traditional principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. Direpack also includes a variety of pre-processing tools, such as generalized spatial signs, along with specialized plotting capabilities and cross-validation utilities. To ensure effortless integration, the package has been designed consistent with the Scikit-Learn API, allowing its estimators to be readily incorporated into various (statistical and/or machine) learning workflows within the framework.

The nonlinear fluorescence emission has been extensively utilized for high-resolution optical imaging. In our study, we investigated the anomalous saturation effect of nitrogen vacancies in diamonds under high-power laser excitation, which led to a significant decrease in fluorescence intensity. This phenomenon substantially augmented the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission, resulting in a modification of the spatial frequency distribution within the fluorescence image. To exploit this effect, we employed a differential excitation protocol, allowing us to retrieve high-frequency details by modulating the excitation laser's power. Our approach yielded approximately 1.6-fold improvement in spatial resolution compared to conventional confocal microscopy. Owing to its straightforward experimental design and data processing, we anticipate that this technique will prove valuable for enhancing the resolution of sensing and biological labeling applications involving solid-state defects.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the conventional approach of using individual survey weights (designed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to create a pseudo-likelihood no longer leads to asymptotically unbiased inference. To address this issue, we propose a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that enables unbiased inference for estimating hyperparameters of the random effects. In comparison with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, our Bayesian approach stands out for its ability to achieve both unbiased estimation with respect to the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Through simulations and a real-data example involving a survey of business establishments, we demonstrate the effectiveness of our method across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work represents a culmination of recent advancements that integrate traditional survey estimation techniques with the Bayesian modeling framework and bridges the gap between these two previously distinct fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, including Res$_2$ and ReSe$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, Group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, borophene, and other similar materials, have intricate atomic structures that diverge from the regular honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The diminished symmetries of these rising stars in material science lead to diverse and inhomogeneous properties, such as electronic, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel characteristics like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, sizable nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Additionally, low-symmetry 2D materials can exhibit unique electronic topological features, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transitions. To bring attention to the latest experimental and theoretical advancements in this exciting field, we have compiled the "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special issue.

The isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups was investigated using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. In a groundbreaking discovery, researchers found that the relaxation of electric birefringence in a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be represented as a sum of multiple exponential processes, with two dominant processes alternating in a temperature range of approximately fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy further revealed two distinct orientational relaxation mechanisms: one attributed to the rotation of side mesogenic groups and another linked to the motion of main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have consistently demonstrated high retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval tasks. However, optimizing discrete hash bits remains a crucial challenge in these methods. A commonly employed strategy involves utilizing an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}$ or $\operatorname{tanh}$, and minimizing a quantization loss to approximating discrete values. Unfortunately, this approach can lead to a phenomenon known as the "dead bits problem" (dbp), where an increasing number of hash bits become trapped in the saturated region of the activation functions, rendering them ineffective. Moreover, the existing quantization loss can exacerbate this issue. To address this problem, we introduce a straightforward yet powerful gradient amplifier that precedes the activation functions, thereby mitigating the effects of dbp.

We investigate the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, which is motivated by the possibility of two-step electroweak symmetry breaking. Our analysis considers two scenarios: either the triplets are stable and contribute to dark matter, or they decay through mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The stability of the triplets is constrained by disappearance searches at the LHC and dark matter direct detection experiments, while their decay is constrained by multilepton collider searches. Our results show that a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is excluded by direct detection searches, whereas an unstable triplet with a mass below $230\ \text{GeV}$ is excluded at the $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings surrounding stars like Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are unexpectedly narrow compared to the conventional eccentric planet perturbation model ("pericenter glow" scenario). According to this scenario, a initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$ has its eccentricity increased to $e_f$ once the gas disk dissipates due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, yielding a belt spanning $2ae_f$. However, in a slight variation of this scenario, the belts may become even narrower if the planetesimals possess initial eccentricities, potentially arising from earlier planet perturbations during the protoplanetary disc stage when the environment was still rich in gas. Alternatively, the primordial eccentricity could stem from instabilities within the disc itself, boosting its eccentricity without necessitating the presence of planets.

Electrons are typically thought to possess a single type of kinetic energy, but what if they could have more? Could their spin and charge contribute to their energetics, or perhaps interactions with other electrons? In one dimension, the Tomonaga-Luttinger liquid (TLL) model effectively captures the behavior of interacting electrons at low energies, but experimental observations beyond this linear regime have been scarce. To address this knowledge gap, we employed a tunneling spectroscopy technique to measure many-body modes in gated 1D wires. Our experiments revealed two distinct Fermi seas at high energies, corresponding to spin and charge excitations, as well as the emergence of three additional 1D replica modes that become more pronounced with decreasing wire length. By varying the amount of 1D inter-subband screening, we were able to modify the effective interaction strength within the wires by over 45%, providing valuable insights into the complex dynamics of interacting electrons in 1D systems.

The Milky Way's assembly history is being revealed through the wealth of data provided by the Gaia mission. The formation path of its globular cluster system is expected to be equally complex. Our aim is to constrain this formation path by investigating the connection between globular clusters and known merging events in the Galaxy's history. To achieve this, we combined Gaia's kinematic information for nearly all galactic clusters with the largest age sample, carefully corrected for systematic errors. By examining their dynamical properties, specifically in integral space, we identified clusters with shared origins. Our results indicate that approximately 40% of the clusters are likely to have formed in situ.

The estimation of a dataset's intrinsic dimension is a crucial step in many dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces Intrinsic, an R package that offers cutting-edge likelihood-based estimators of intrinsic dimension. The package includes three innovative models: Two-NN, Gride, and Hidalgo. To facilitate their use, Intrinsic provides several high-level, user-friendly functions that leverage a comprehensive set of efficient, low-level routines. These models can be classified into two groups: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The former includes Two-NN and Gride, whose inference is performed using both frequentist and Bayesian approaches. Hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, falls under the latter category and features an efficient Gibbs sampler implementation.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamics and recurrent behavior at the nanosecond scale, which holds great promise for enabling spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. In fact, we have proposed and modeled two physical RC systems based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs) to tackle image classification tasks and predict nonlinear dynamic systems, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulations reveal that the MSM-based RC system demonstrates exceptional performance in recognizing handwritten digits, while the STNO-based RC system can effectively solve complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems, as demonstrated in a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms play a vital role in various online platforms, including search engines and recommender systems. In this study, we uncover a fascinating phenomenon associated with popularity-based rankings: the fewer the items sharing a particular signal, the greater the combined traffic they attract. This "few-get-richer" effect materializes in environments characterized by limited item diversity (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news sources) and popularity-based ranking. By analyzyzing user behavior and preference heterogeneity, we demonstrate the emergence of this effect through both theoretical modeling and simulation. Furthermore, we validate our predictions through experimental testing involving human participants. The insights gained from this research carry significant implications for understanding the dissemination of misinformation.

Weight pruning has long been recognized as a simple yet powerful technique for eliminating redundant neurons in deep neural networks (DNNs) and enhancing their performance across diverse platforms. However, many existing pruning methods involve compromising between model accuracy and regularity, ultimately leading to diminished inference precision and restricted accelerated performance on devices. To address this challenge, we propose introducing a novel sparsity dimension, dubbed pattern-based sparsity, which combines the benefits of pattern and connectivity sparsity. By incorporating carefully crafted patterns, our innovative pruning strategy consistently and significantly improves accuracy and feature extraction capabilities across various DNN architectures and datasets. Moreover, our pattern-aware pruning framework efficiently performs pattern library extraction, pattern selection, connectivity pruning, and weight training in tandem. The resulting approach seamlessly integrates with compiler optimizations, paving the way for highly efficient DNN execution on resource-constrained mobile devices.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group significantly distinct from the treated group is susceptible to historical event bias. This occurs when historical events impact the groups disparately. To mitigate this bias, creating a more comparable control group by matching a subset of the total control group to the treated group can be effective. We investigate this phenomenon through simulation studies. Specifically, we examine the relationship between mortality and mountaintop removal mining (MRM) using a difference-in-differences approach that capitalizes on the MRM increase subsequent to the 1990 Clean Air Act Amendments. Our findings indicate that by constructing a more closely matched control group, we obtained a 95% confidence interval encompassing considerable adverse effects alongside negligible and modest beneficial effects.

When building models to summarize clinical data for simulation purposes, it's essential to assess their ability to replicate the original data. Visual predictive checks (VPCs) offer a reliable approach to do this. The process involves three steps: (1) simulate the original study multiple times using the model being evaluated; (2) calculate estimates of interest for each simulated study; and (3) compare the distribution of these estimates with the actual estimate from the original study. This method is generally applicable and straightforward to implement. In this context, we focus on its application to time-to-event data, specifically addressing the scenario where a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event occurs.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling open quantum systems using sequential schemes are presented. Our discussion centers around protocols that rely on a combination of repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses to achieve three key objectives: (i) confining and protecting quantum dynamics from decoherence, consistent with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically predicting the probability of transferring a quantum system into a target state through stochastic sequential measurements; and (iii) optimally reconstructing the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing filter functions in the frequency domain for designed quantum sensors. Accomplishing these goals will significantly enhance our ability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thereby advancing quantum science and technology.

Palms sweating, heart pounding, stomach twisted in knots - you're unable to call out for help. It's not just that your throat feels constricted, making it difficult to breathe; it would also be mortifying. You're not facing a monster, but something that, for many, is even more daunting: public speaking. While death may bring oblivion, standing in front of an audience fills you with a sense of dread that's hard to shake off. However, since we've all had to address a crowd at some point, it's essential to learn how to cope with this fear. To begin, let's recognize what stage fright is. As social creatures, humans are programmed to anxiously guard their reputation. When we speak in public, there's a lingering concern that our words might damage our image, leaving us feeling exposed and vulnerable. The thought of embarrassment looms large before a speech, as we worry, "What if they think I'm terrible? What if I come across as an idiot?"

It's hard to imagine someone having only one interest in life that they want to pursue forever. Instead, many Americans diversify their professional lives, with around 15% of workers holding non-traditional jobs such as part-time, temporary, or freelance positions. This phenomenon aligns with the concept of a "side hustle," which has its origins in African American culture during the early 20th century. Initially used to describe fraudulent schemes, the term evolved by the 1950s to encompass legitimate means of earning a living as well. While a second job is often motivated by financial needs, a side hustle differs in that it involves various ventures or projects that may offer personal fulfillment, creative outlets, or additional income streams.

Two twin domes, symbolizing contrasting design philosophies. One dome comprises thousands of metallic components, while the other is crafted from a singular silk strand. One embodies artificiality, the other, organicity. One imposes its will upon the environment; the other, a creation of nature itself. One is tailored for natural habitation, the other, an artistic reflection of it. Michelangelo once observed that within raw marble, a figure yearned to break free. His chisel served as the key to unlocking its potential. However, living entities do not conform to such sculptural constraints. They develop and flourish autonomously. Deep within our biological blueprints, our cells contain the intricate instructions necessary for their own functional longevity and propagation. Tools, too, bear repercussions. Since the advent of the Industrial Revolution, the realm of design has been shaped by the principles of large-scale fabrication and standardized production.

Hi there! I'm Simone. Have you ever heard the advice to imagine the audience naked when you're on stage and feeling nervous? Well, I've been thinking, and let's be real, that approach doesn't quite sit right with me in 2018. It's important that we move beyond objectifying others, don't you think? Instead, I've come up with a different solution. I'd love it if I could look at you all as much as you're looking at me – just to level the playing field a bit. That way, if I had multiple eyes, we'd all feel nice and comfortable, wouldn't we?

While it holds truth for certain activities like emailing during meals or texting while driving, I argue that for some tasks, doing multiple things simultaneously is not only feasible but desirable. Albert Einstein provides a compelling example; in 1905, he published four groundbreaking scientific papers, demonstrating that simultaneous productivity can lead to exceptional achievements."
